subNodes.conversationText:
"More or less, less or more.
There's the chair, and there's the door.
There's a house without a floor.
There's an apple, there's its core."
"You're almost ready. You're young for a witch, but there's no shame in that," said Eldest Lady, pinching <FirstName>'s cheek. It hurt.
"No shame in being young? I did lots of shameful things when I was young," said Middle One wistfully.
"You did them shamelessly. The old do shame with shame in their hearts."
"Then you're as good as young, sister. No shame, no heart."
"You heard what happened to Nnenne, the last witch we bound to us?"
"The bird who fetched you was useless."
"<He/She>'s here now," said Eldest Lady. "That's what matters."
"Was off picking blackberries to make us tarts."
"But we're tarts already, so she quit."
"No, Middle One. She quit because she was shot."
"When we found her, she was dead. She'd run a mile with the arrow in her side."
"That's very sad. May the Wooden Crone be kinder to me."
"A hunter. But more of that later."
"What does this have to do with my coven-binding?"
"We want you to find the killer."
"More importantly, we want you to bring us the killer's blood. We'll use it for the binding."

"Yes, bring it! Bring it! What does the hunter's blood taste like? Bring it to us."

Roused, Pharaoh stretched his wings and bobbed his head.
"No, Middle One. There will be no tasting."
[Folk Magic] "Blood? I've never heard of a coven-binding that required blood."
"Perhaps not," said Eldest Lady, annoyed, "but I require it."
"She needs the blood to warm her own." Middle One cackled.
"We'll appease Nnenne with her killer's blood and anoint the one who follows her with the same. It's all very suitable."
"And whose blood would I be bringing if you had no one to avenge?"
"Very well. I will hunt this hunter."
[Folk Magic] "Blood? I've never heard of a coven-binding that required blood."
"Perhaps not," said Eldest Lady, annoyed, "but I require it."
[Folk Magic] "Blood? I've never heard of a coven-binding that required blood."
"Perhaps not," said Eldest Lady, annoyed, "but I require it."
[Folk Magic] "Blood? I've never heard of a coven-binding that required blood."
"Perhaps not," said Eldest Lady, annoyed, "but I require it."
[Folk Magic] "Blood? I've never heard of a coven-binding that required blood."
"Perhaps not," said Eldest Lady, annoyed, "but I require it."
"And whose blood would I be bringing if you had no one to avenge?"
"If we had no one to avenge," said Eldest Lady, "you wouldn't be here."
"Very well. I will hunt this hunter."
"Very well. I will hunt this hunter."

"Good. The arrow, Middle One."

Middle One held forth an arrow. It was long and straight, and its fletching was made of goose feathers. Dried blood was on the point.

Eldest Lady spoke again. "Three hunters live in these woods. Take this arrow and find the one who shoots with arrows of the same make. Kill the hunter and bring back a pint of their blood."

"Good. Just one more thing."

"Go into the backyard. There you'll find Nnenne's grave. Nearby is a little table with a seed, trowel, and some water."

"Dig a hole in the grave, plant the seed, and water it."

Tall grasses and wildflowers had overtaken the witches' backyard. Abandoned charms, half-empty jars, and rusty tools were strewn through the grass.

Near the border of the woods was a fresh grave, dug between two vegetable patches where tomato plants sprawled. A shaft of sunlight illuminated the plot and a name crudely carved on the stone marker. "NNENNE," it said.

heard someone lock the door behind . The witches would not let back in until had finished task.

actions.a_parameter_1: THE THREE HUNTERS has been added to journal.

subNodes.conversationText: "This arrow can't conclusively prove who did this."
"Are you a witch or a lawyer? Aroint thee, clerk."
"Blood talks. Get the blood and then we'll know for sure."
"Not a very efficient way of pursuing justice."
"What is flesh to the Crone? You're young, <FirstName>, but it's time to set aside these young ideas. The world is old and wicked."
"Then may I take the right blood."
"No, no. What the hunter did was very wrong. Therefore, you must take the wrong blood."
"Don't listen to Middle One's nonsense. You will choose rightly."
"We'll direct you. But we have a gift for you first."
"Very well. About this arrow, though -- it can't conclusively prove who did this."
"Are you a witch or a lawyer? Aroint thee, clerk."
"A hunter. But more of that later."
"Very well. I hope the Wooden Crone is kinder to me."
"What does this have to do with my coven-binding?"
"Who knows? She was a witch, and witches are not always loved. She was beautiful -- and there are people who hate beauty more than witches."
"How sad! May the Wooden Crone be kinder to me."
"What does this have to do with my coven-binding?"
"We want you to find the killer."
"What does this have to do with me?"
"Very well. I hope the Wooden Crone is kinder to me."
"We want you to find the killer."
"Enough. Go dampen firewood. If the firewood's all wet, warp floorboards. As for you," said Eldest Lady to <FirstName>, "we need to talk about some things. You know the Laws, yes?"
"The Three Laws of Covens? Of course."
"Do no harm to anyone in the coven --" <FirstName> began.
" -- including yourself. Naught but death or unbinding dissolves a coven. Finally, the witches' number must always be odd."
"Every witch knows the Laws, but they're not just words. Without a third, Middle One and I do not make a coven. Our powers are weak." She shook her head. "It has been too long."
"You heard what happened to Nnenne, the last witch we bound to us?"
"Rule number one: 'The youngest witch gets the biggest bed.'"
"One: Do no harm to anyone in the coven -- including yourself. Two: Naught but death or unbinding dissolves a coven. Three: The witches' number must always be odd."
But <FirstName> drew a blank. "I've forgotten. I must be too nervous."
"One: Do no harm to anyone in the coven -- including yourself. Two: Naught but death or unbinding dissolves a coven. Three: The witches' number must always be odd."
The two witches had been waiting for <him/her>. Middle One and Eldest Lady were their names. They were quick to get to the point.
